loans.name: Tsendmaa

texts.en:
Tsendmaa is a 50-year-old hardworking and active woman who lives with her retired husband in suburban Ulaanbaatar. Her children are grown and live independently.

In 2005 Tsendmaa went into hairdressing after getting trained. She has gained number of regular customers and is well-known in the area. She said, "In the future I plan to expand my business so I can serve my customers well.”

Tsendmaa’s husband is seriously ill. She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan from XacBank to pay her husband’s medical fees.

loans.use: to pay her husband’s medical fees.

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
Analiza, a 39-year-old married mother of three children, lives in Dinas, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental, where, for the last 12 years, she manages their coconut farm. This farm gives her an income of 3,000, which enables her to send her children to school.

Analiza has been a member of GDMPC for 4 years. She has requested a loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. In the future, she wishes to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise

loans.name: Teofilo Joffre

texts.es: Teofilo tiene 33 años, es casado y tiene 3 hijos. Vive en el sector conocido como el Fortín. Nelly su esposa es ama de casa. Sus hijos tienen 8, 9 y 11 años de edad y estudian en la escuela fiscal. Su profesión es farmacólogo pero tiene su negocio propio. Desde 1995 comenzó a hacer shampo que vende en su casa, hace un año inicio la tienda y bazar. Su horario de trabajo es desde las 6 de la mañana hasta las 8 de la tarde contando con la ayuda de su esposa en la atención. En su negocio vende artículos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar, cuadernos, lápices, químicos etc. Teofilo nos cuenta que mayores dificultades no tiene, pero en la época invernal las calles se dañan y complican el transporte. Este es su 5 crédito el cual lo va a invertir en aumentar su negocio comprando arroz, azúcar, aceite, cuadernos etc. En próximos años le gustaría que su negocio crezca más.
texts.en:
Teofilo, age 33, is married and has three children.  He lives in the sector known as El Fortín.  Nelly, his wife, is a housewife.  His children are 8, 9, and 11 years old, and they attend the public school.

He is a pharmacologist by profession, but he has his own business.  In 1995 he started to make shampoo that he sells at his house.  He started the store a year ago.  His work schedule is from six in the morning until eight at night.  His wife helps him with the store.  

In his business he sells basic needs items like rice, sugar, notebooks, pencils, and chemicals, etc.  Teofilo tells us that he does not have any major difficulties.  However, during the winter the streets get damaged, and that complicates transportation.

This is his fifth loan.  He will use it to expand his business by purchasing rice, sugar, oil, and notebooks, etc.  In the coming years he would like his business to grow more.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, and notebooks.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is 49 years old, married and has five children. She lives in Estrella in Sinacaban municipality located in Misamis Occidental Province. For the past seven years Helen has sold seedlings and young plants to local farmers. She earns 1,500 a month in this business.

In 2010, Helen joined GDMPC. She is requesting a 3,000 PHP loan that will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young plants to raise. She plans to use her additional profits to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young plants to raise.

loans.name: Oyunmaa

texts.en: Oyunmaa is a 28-year-old woman who lives with her mother and 2 siblings in a suburban area of Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. Her mother is unemployed and her siblings study at school. She started a food kiosk business in 2011 in a well-positioned corner. As the business became famous locally, she is planning to increase the types of products. Oyunmaa is a hardworking and active young woman who says, "I would like to expand the business activities by increasing the product types. I have a further plan to open my own store". The total amount she is requesting is 500,000 MNT to buy food supplies.

loans.use: To buy food supplies

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is 29 years old and lives in Burgos, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is married with two children. 

Nancy is engaged in the buying and selling of coconuts. She has had this business for three years. She requested a loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy additional working capital.

Nancy has been a member of PMPC for six years.  In the future, Nancy hopes to own a house and lot someday.

loans.use: to buy coconuts to sell

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica is from Dinas, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 53 years old, married, and has three children. Veronica owns and operates a business planting and harvesting sugarcane "tubo" to sell. She has been in her business for 12 years and earns 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2008, Veronica joined GDMPC. Veronica is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, such as manure

loans.name: Arcelita

texts.en: Arcelita is married with three children. She is 35 years old and lives in Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Arcelita manages their garden business, where she plants root crops to earn a living. She has been in this business for five years and earns 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) each month. She requested a loan of 5,000 (PHP) to purchase farm chemicals. Arcelita has been a member of Kiva's partner GDMPC for just this year. In the future, Arcelita's plan is to save her returns in order to buy a new house.

loans.use: to purchase farm chemicals.

loans.name: Juvitha

texts.en:
Juvitha is 39 years old and widowed with four children. She lives in Caputol in Aloran municipality, Misamis Occidental Province. She is a farmer who has grown rice for the past fifteen years.

Juvitha has been a member of PMPC for six years. She has requested a 20,000 PHP loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides, as well as to redeem some coconut plantation land she had to pawn.

Juvitha’s ambition is to have a good future.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides, as well as to redeem some coconut plantation land.

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine is is 37 years old and married with three children. She lives in Tuyabang Bajo, a part of Oroquieta City. For the past six years she has had a business fattening hogs, earning approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

Geraldine has been a member of PMPC for eight years. She is requesting a 14,900 PHP loan to buy piglets and feed for them. Geraldine’s ambition is to own a piggery someday.

loans.use: to buy piglets and feed for them.

loans.name: Arlina

texts.en:
Arlina, 45, started raising poultry three years ago. Her income went toward providing the necessities needed for her family. But due to the high cost of living, she wasn’t making enough.

For this reason, Arlina is asking for a 9,000 PHP loan from ASKI to buy additional ducklings, chickens and poultry food. Her ambition is to realize higher profits. In this way she will be able to better provide for the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional ducklings, chickens and poultry food.

loans.name: Francisco

texts.en: Francisco is married with four children. He is 50 years old and resides in Tagulalo, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. Francisco used his last loan to purchase more coloring materials for his decoration-making business. His business is successful, and he is taking a new loan to purchase more rolls of string made from lagpakanay (a kind of plant). In the future, he hopes to be able to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase more rolls of lagpakanay string.

loans.name: Maria Isidora

texts.es: La señora maría labora en el ministerio de educación de un municipio del departamento de león, desempeñándose como conserje del mismo, con 8 años de ejercer dicha actividad, su nucleo familiar lo componen su esposo y un hijo ya casado, la señora maría presenta un problema de salud y para tratárselo de manera completa decidió visitar ceprodel para solicitar un financiamiento y poderse efectuar dicho tratamiento ya que el mismo le daría la oportunidad misma de efectuárselo ya que es costoso y solo con la ayuda de ceprodel  puede salir adelante y tener mejores condiciones y nivel de vida, ya que lo utilizara para pago de exámenes, compra de medicamento, tomarse unas placas y pago de consulta.
texts.en: María works for the Ministry of Education, in a town in León department.  She works as a janitor.  She has been in this job for eight years.  Her nuclear family is made up of her husband and a son who is already married.  María has a health problem and, in order to completely treat her illness, she decided to visit Ceprodel to request a loan to pay for treatment.  The loan will give her the opportunity to have the treatment, which is costly.  María can only make progress and enjoy better conditions and a better standard of living with Ceprodel's help.  She will use her loan to pay for examinations, buy medicines, have some x-rays done and pay for doctors' visits.

loans.use: to pay for medical expenses such as examinations, medicines, x-rays and doctors' visits

loans.name: June

texts.en: June is married with three children. He is 51 years old and resides at Lintugop, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur, Philippines. June used his last loan to purchase additional ingredients for making buko salad. His business is successful, and he is taking a new loan to repair his motorcycle which he uses for delivery in his business. In the future he hopes to be able to expand his business.

loans.use: to repair his motorcycle which he uses in his business for delivery.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine runs a stall inside the public market of Santiago. She sells onions and bananas. She is 46 years of age, married, and has two children. She and her husband both work hard in order to succeed.

Josephine has been a market vendor for 15 years. According to her, patience, dedication, and financial support are what have allowed her to improve her business. Josephine would like to have continued business improvement so that she can earn greater income, which will serve to cover all her family's daily needs.

Josephine would like to apply for a loan in the amount of 30,000 PHP, which will allow her to buy more onions and bananas for her fruit and vegetable business. She hopes for her business will grow so that she can send her children through a higher level of education.

In the picture, Josephine is wearing a yellow blouse while her Project Officer wears white and violet.

loans.use: to buy more onions and bananas for her fruits-and-vegetables business

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita works hard to support her family. She is married and has a food-vending business in the Philippines. Lolita has been in this business for 30 years.

Lolita has requested a loan of 18000 PHP through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food-vending business.

In the future, Lolita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food-vending business.

loans.name: Erdenebat

texts.en: Erdenebat is 51 years old. He is a taxi driver in the city of Ulaanbaatar. He has a son and daughter. He has been running a taxi service since 2002 and his daily income is not enough for his life. Last year he took a loan to build a new ger as a wedding gift for his son. This time he needs some money to buy another car for expanding his business. His son Khishigbaasan will use that car for a taxi business too. As he believes it will be beneficial to increase his family income and support his son, the loan he is taking will be dedicated to cover the cost of his purchasing a car.

loans.use: To cover the cost of purchasing a car.

loans.name: Dios Es Amor Group

texts.es: La Sra. Josefina  tiene  57  años de edad,  es casada  y tiene 2 hijos , josefina  actualmente es socia en la alcancía comunal “Dios es amor” grupo  conformado por 8  socios que se dedica a la venta de  actividades de comercio.  Josefina   se dedica a la venta de juguetes  desde hace 20 años en un puesto en el mercado a su vez también vende cuadernos y lapiceros. Josefina  inicia este negocio con el fin de ayudar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar y que su familia cuente con una mejor calidad de vida,  gracias a su esfuerzo y dedicación   sus hijos ya están en la universidad, se ha comprado un terreno y ha construido su casa. Josefina   ha solicitado un nuevo préstamo para comprar mercadería juguetes y cuadernos es decir útiles escolares.  Josefina cumplirá sus metas con mucho trabajo y esfuerzo y que los préstamos de Edaprospo le ayudaran
texts.en:
Josefina, 57, is married and has two children. Josefina is currently a member of the communal bank “Dios es amor” [God is love] which consists of 8 members that are make their living selling retail goods. 

Josefina has sold toys for 20 years in a market stall and, at the same time, also sells notebooks and pens. Josefina started this business in order to help her husband with household expenses and so her family could have a better quality of life.  Thanks to her efforts and dedication, her children are in college, she bought a piece of land, and built her home. 

Josefina has requested a new loan to buy toys and school supplies such as notebooks. Josefina will meet her goals with hard work and effort and the loans from Edaprospo will help her.

loans.use: to buy toys and school supplies

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is 38 years old and married with two children. She earns a living by farming vegetables in the Philippines. Judith has been farming vegetables for 12 years and also earns additional income from raising pigs. 

Judith is borrowing 15000 PHP through NWTF to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Oyuntulkhuur

texts.en:
Mrs. Oyuntulkhuur, 24, lives with her husband and son in her small house located in the ger district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband works a splumber in the summer, while she has been working as a cashier with a private company since 2007.

In 2008, Oyuntulkhuur bought a small plot of land with money she had saved over many years. She subsequently began the construction of her current house but lacks sufficient funds to finish the interior. She is therefore requesting a loan of 2.000.000MNT to purchase the building materials needed to complete its interior decoration, which she and her husband will do themselves.

loans.use: to purchase the building materials needed to complete her house's interior decoration.

loans.name: Gankhuyag

texts.en:
Mr. Gankhuyag, 42, drives a taxi around the districts of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He has been running his business nonstop since 2003, and his daily earnings are about 15-20 USD in a whole day. Currently the business is a main income source for his family. 

Gankhuyag wants to start a second business, selling used clothes in the outdoor bazaar.  He expects that it will increase his family income in the future. He needs 2,000,000 MNT to rent the stall in order to sell clothes in the bazaar. Mr. Gankhuyag has experience of this business; he used to sell clothes in another bazaar.

loans.use: To rent a stall to sell clothes in the bazaar.

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina lives in Buluk. She has a food stall, and has been in business for two years. She is 45 years old, married, and has three children; two of them are still in school. 

Lina heard about BRAC South Sudan from a credit officer. This is her fifth loan from BRAC. She has requested a loan of 2500 Sudanese pounds in order to purchase ice cream and beans. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay the school fees.

loans.use: to purchase ice cream and beans to sell

loans.name: Lengtry's Group

texts.en:
Lengtry is a 51 year-old mother living in Kandal province. She has five children, three of whom are staying with the family and are still in school. 

She has been growing sugarcane and vegetables to support the family for more than 20 years. This is Lengtry’s fourth loan with VisionFund. She now leads a group of three members, all of whom are female. She requested the loan to buy fertilizers and vegetables seeds. This loan will enable Lengtry to plant more sugarcane and vegetables and increase her income so that she can support her family better.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and vegetables seeds.

loans.name: Norma

texts.es: La  señora   norma es  una persona  muy  trabajadora  la  cual junto  con su esposo  se   preocupan por  brindarle  lo   mejor  a  sus  hijos, ella  se acerco  a la  institución ya  que   requiere  acondicionar  su  vivienda, desea construir una  barda  en  su casa ve  en el crédito  la  posibilidad  de  que  su   hogar  se encuentre  protegido  y a si  cuando  los  dos  salgan  a trabajar  lo harán de  una  manera  mas  tranquila , por  lo  que  están  muy  contentos  de habernos  encontrado y  muy  agradecidos  por   la  facilidad  para  realizar los pagos.
texts.en: Norma is a very hardworking person who together with her husband strives to provide the best for their children.  She approached the institution because she needs to upgrade her house.  She wants to build a wall at home and sees in the loan the possibility of her house becoming better protected so that when they go to work they can do so with more peace of mind.  They are very happy to have found us and very grateful for the easy payment terms.

loans.use: to build a wall for her home.

loans.name: Channo's Group

texts.en:
Channo is a 51-year-old widowed mother who has two children. She has been planting vegetables for almost 20 years to support the family. Both of Channo’s kids are working at a factory in Kandal province. 

Channo has been with VisionFund since 2010. Having completely repaid her previous loan, she applied for the second loan aiming to get the money to buy vegetable seeds and fertilizers, and now she leads a loan group of two female members. She wishes that this loan from VisionFund will enable her to better feed her family.

loans.use: To buy vegetable seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Alfa Y Omega Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “ALFA Y OMEGA” iniciará su primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Senkata, está compuesta por siete integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva encabezada por la señora Gladys. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: venta de carne de cerdo, asfalto de construcción, venta de ropa americana, venta de artículos varios, comerciante de vajillas.

La señora Gladys,  indica que este es el primer ciclo que trabaja con Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una asesora. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de tienda de barrio, que inicio hace años, aprendiendo el mismo de su madre.

El crédito que ahora sacará es para aumentar su capital (compra de abarrotes), que compraran de la ciudad de El Alto y los venderán todos los días por las mañanas y por las tardes en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su familia, pues ella es casada y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el ahorro y el área de salud.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Alfa y Omega” will start their first loan cycle with Pro Mujer, as part of the Senkata centre. The group is composed of 7 members and is directed by a governing board led by Gladys. The businesses that the members of the communal bank have are varied, among them are: pork sales, asphalt for construction, American clothes sales, miscellaneous goods sales, and a crockery trader.

Gladys says that this is the first loan she will take with Pro Mujer. She came to it through the invitation of a Pro Mujer adviser.  She now runs a small local grocery store that she started years ago, something she learnt from her mother. The loan she will get will help her increase her capital to purchase groceries that she will get from the city of El Alto and then sell every day, in the mornings and afternoons, in her store. This way of works allows her to generate resources to support her family as much as possible, being that she is married and has 3 children.

When she is asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she says she likes the savings and the health service.

loans.use: to puchase groceries

loans.name: Cenelia Elizabeth

texts.es: Esta señora es originaria de telica, su profesión es maestra de primaria, está ubicada en el colegio de una  comarca de telica, tiene 18 años de laborar en dicha actividad, su núcleo familiar está compuesto por una hija y su esposo la que estudia en un colegio de la localidad y que tiene el deber de proporcionarle las condiciones necesarias para que se desarrolle, esta señora está presentando un problema de salud el que le impide entregarse toda a su labor y para eso decidió visitar a ceprodel para ser beneficiada con un financiamiento y mejorar esa situación para brindar la enseñanza esencial y elevar su rendimiento académico de sus alumnos y de esa manera mejorar sus condiciones de vida y de su familia.
texts.en: This lady comes from Telica, she a primary school teacher working in a school located in a rural area of the Telica jurisdiction. She has been teaching for 18 years old, and she has a husband and a daughter who attends a school of her community, for whom she has to provide the necessary chances of a social development. This borrower is suffering from a health condition forbidding her to work fully and proficiently, and for this reason she has decided to come to Ceprodel to ask for a loan. She wants to improve her health to provide basic schooling to her students and to help them improve their academic achievement; she also wants to improve her standard of living as well as that of her family.

loans.use: To pay for medical expenses.

loans.name: Gantsetseg

texts.en: Gantsetseg, 41, has sold baby clothes in the supermarket since 2008. She buys her goods from the Chinese border city. She lives with her husband and her 2 daughters in a ger, a Mongolian traditional nomadic yurt in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. In summer time she has a big sales volume due to the increased demand for baby clothes. Most of her customers have a good opinion of her goods and their quality. Now she needs 2,300,000 MNT to buy baby clothes to increase her working capital for a bigger sales volume in the next coming months. In addition it is her second loan and she was able to repay her previous loan on time successfully.

loans.use: To buy baby clothes to increase her working capital for a bigger sales volume in the next coming months

loans.name: Lucio Felix

texts.es:
Lucio   es un hombre  que tiene  39 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, con tres hijos a su cargo, vive con su cónyuge y sus hijos en casa propia. Se menciona que  La calidad de vida en la comunidad es de subsistencia, la mayoría de moradores  son trabajadores independientes  que se dedican al comercio, agricultura y ganadería. Lucio  vive  en el  caserío Las Mònicas del distrito de Tambogrande, departamento de Piura; así mismo cuenta con el servicio básico de energía eléctrica; también se menciona que en este distrito viven todas las  familias bajo estas condiciones.
La actividad comercial a la que se dedica Lucio es al transporte público de mototaxi el recorrido lo realiza entre las zonas de Las Monicas  – Tambogrande y visciversa. Además se dedica a la crianza y engorde de aves de corral, y además cuenta con 1 ha de terreno agrícola sembrado de limón y leguminosas generándole otros ingresos para cubrir gastos propios; cabe destacar que en esta actividad  de transporte público Lucio cuenta con 6 años de experiencia, lo que le ha permitido mantener su clientela ya establecida en este negocio. 
Actualmente  Lucio esta solicitando un nuevo préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa por un monto de S/. 1000 nuevos soles que será para el mantenimiento de su vehiculo (cambio de neumáticos, carpa y cambio de aceite),  y compra de alimentos para sus animales esto debido a que es una actividad muy rentable en la zona; lo cual en el tiempo le va permitir ir mejorando su nivel de vida con su familia.
texts.en:
Lucio is a 39 year old man living with his common-law wife and caring for 3 children. They all live in their own home. It should be mentioned that the quality of life in this community is that of just getting by. The majority of people are indigenous and work independently in commerce, agriculture, and with livestock. Lucio lives in Las Monicas in the district of Tambogrande, in Piura. He has basic electricity in his home, and in his district every family lives with those conditions Lucio works in public transportation with a mototaxi driving the routes between Las Monicas and Tambogrande. He also works raising and fattening poultry and also has 1 hectare of land where he grows limes and legumes to earn additional money for his expenses. He has 6 years of experience in public transportation, and has maintained regular clients and established himself in the business.

Lucio is asking for a new loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 1,000 nuevos soles that will be used for vehicle maintenance (tire change, awning, and oil change) and to buy animal food, since this activity is very profitable in his area. In time, this will allow him to improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: buy tires, an awning, an oil change, and animal feed.

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.en: Ana Maria is married with four children. She is 45 years old and lives in the Philippines. Ana Maria used her last loan to pay for the cost of canvassing supplies and delivery. Her business has grown up and become successful. As proof of this success, she is now managing her agricultural business. She's taking a new loan to purchase fertilizers and seedlings for the next cropping. Thinking positively, she hopes to be able to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seedlings for the next cropping

location.town: Campo 5, Ramon Magsaysay, Zamboanga Del Sur

loans.name: Erdenebat

texts.en:
Erdenebat is a 54 year-old man who lives with his wife and a daughter in Selenge province in Northern Mongolia. His wife is employed and his daughter is a college student. He started a car spare part retail business in 2003. He purchases the supplies from Russia and trades them at the capital city market in wholesale. He has number of regular reliable customers. The business activities are stable. Erdenebat is a talented businessman on the field and he says: "I would like to expand the business activities by purchasing the spare parts in large quantities. I am planning to improve the family livelihood level." 

The total amount he is requesting is 2,700,000 MNT to buy spare parts in wholesale.

loans.use: To buy spare parts in wholesale

loans.name: Channy's Group

texts.en: Channy and her family live in a wooden house in Kandal province. As a mother of two, she has been growing vegetables and sugar cane for over 20 years. All of her children are working at the plantation too. Channy and another member of the group are now requesting a fifth loan from Kiva partner VisionFund. Channy will use her portion of the loan to buy vegetables seeds and fertilizers for her crops. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her crop yield in order to produce more income for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her crops, and vegetables seeds.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 38 years old and lives in the town of Arua in the Arua region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, two of whom are currently in school. Grace has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells small dried fish. 
To help expand her business, Grace has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more small dried fish for resale, and will help Grace to generate greater profits and ensure a better standard of living for her family. Grace hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business. 
Grace is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Grace who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to buy more small dried fish for resale,

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher is 35 years old and lives in the town of Arua in the Arua region of Uganda. He is married and has four children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past ten years, Christopher has been working hard to manage his small business, which sells clothes. 
To help expand his business, Christopher has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes for resale, and will help Christopher to generate greater profits and increase his capital. Christopher hopes that in the future he will be able to grow into a bigger business. 
Christopher is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Christopher who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Maria Del Socorro

texts.es: Esta señora es originaria de una comarca de telica, es maestra de primaria y está ubicada  en el colegio de la localidad,  tiene 13 años de laborar, su núcleo familiar  consta de 3 personas que son sus hijos, los que estudian en un colegio de la localidad, a los que tiene que proporcionarles su preparación,  su esposo trabaja en la empresa en león, esta señora se acerco a ceprodel para ser beneficiada con un financiamiento ya que tiene la necesidad urgente de mejorar su vivienda la que está en mal estado y lo utilizara para la compra de materiales de construcción como: Cemento, Arena Ayudante y Mano de Obra, para efectuar un repello en la pared y mejorar sus condiciones y nivel de vida.
texts.en: This lady comes rural area of the Telica jurisdiction. She is a primary school teacher working in a school of her community, and she has been teaching for 13 years. She has 3 children who attend the community school and for who she has to provide an education; her husband works in a company in León. This lady came to Ceprodel to ask for a loan as she needs to urgently make improvements to her house; as it is in a bad state, she will use the loan to buy construction materials such as cement and sand, and to pay for laborers. She needs to whitewash one wall, and she aims at improving her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy construction materials such as cement and sand, and to pay for laborers.

loans.name: Judith Guadalupe

texts.es: Judith nació en Echendia pero actualmente vive en Guayaquil con su familia. Tiene 34 años, está casada con Jhonny quien trabaja como vendedor en la empresa Pulido Costura S.A. Tiene 2 hijos, el de 9 años estudia en la escuela  y el de 3 está a su cargo. El bazar lo inicio hace 9 años por motivo que quedo desempleada y ese fue el empuje que tuvo para emprenderlo. No tiene hora fija pero siempre abre de lunes a domingo de 6 am hasta las 8 pm. En la época de lluvia no vende mucho porque las calles se dañan y los vehículos no llegan hasta su domicilio. Con el préstamo va a ampliar su negocio comprando cuadernos, láminas y artículos de primera necesidad (arroz, azúcar, aceite, granos). Su próxima meta es ampliar su casa y su negocio.
texts.en:
Judith was born in Echendia, but currently lives in Guayaquil with her family. She is 34 years old, and is married to Jhonny, who works as a salesman for the Pulido Costura SA company. She has two children. One is nine and goes to school, and the other is three and stays with her. She opened her stationery store nine years ago, because she became unemployed, and that was what pushed her to get started. She doesn't have a fixed schedule but she is always open Monday through Sunday from 6:00 am to 8:00 pm. During the rainy season she doesn't sell as much because the streets get damaged and vehicles can't reach her residence. 
She is going to use the loan to expand her business by purchasing notebooks, paper, and essential goods (rice, sugar, oil, grains). Her next goal is to expand her home and her business.

loans.use: to purchase notebooks and paper.

loans.name: Caminantes Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “CAMINANTES” iniciará el ciclo quinto en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Collpani, está compuesta por ocho integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva encabezada por la señora Ignacia. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: venta de fruta, venta de colonias y perfumes, venta de edredones, venta de detergentes, tejido de chompas a mano, venta de fresco y gelatina, venta de verduras, venta de carne.

La señora Ignacia, indica que hace veintidós años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una la promotora. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de cultivo y  venta de fruta, mismo que viene trabajando hace años, aprendiendo el mismo desde su niñez.

El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de semilla), que comprará de la las tiendas distribuidoras y posteriormente lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su familia, pues ella es casada y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el ahorro
texts.en:
The communal bank "Caminantes" [Walkers] will initiate its fifth loan cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the regional office in Collpani. This group is composed of eight members and is led by a board of directors headed by Ignacia. The businesses that the members of the association are engaged in vary between them and include: the sale of fruit, colognes and perfumes, quilts, detergents, hand woven sweaters, sodas and gelatin, vegetables, and the sale of meat.

Ignacia, explains that she has worked with Pro Mujer for twenty-two years, entering the group at the invitation of a promoter.  Currently, she has a business growing and selling fruit.  She has carried this work out for many years, learning the same trade since her childhood.  The loan that she will take now is to raise capital for seeds that she will purchase from the supply stores, and later market in her own retail space.  This type of work will allow her to generate resources to help her family to the greatest extent possible, as she is married and has three children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she replies that she likes the savings.

loans.use: to purchase seeds.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen is a 34-year-old married man with four children living in Kasese, Uganda. He is a teacher by profession and has been in service for 10 years. He says he has so far achieved his dream of being a teacher. It was his childhood passion, but the only challenge is the meager salary attached. He desires to build a permanent house for residence, buy land to grow crops, and educate his children to attain higher qualifications than his. Stephen wants to borrow money to buy land for growing crops.

loans.use: to buy land for growing crops.

loans.name: Herbert

texts.en: Herbert wants a loan to service his taxi. He is a 53-year-old married man with four children living in Masindi, Uganda. He has been in the transport sector for ten years and he bought the car from his salary savings as a civil servant. His dreams are to educate his children, build a permanent house, and buy a bus for his transport business.

loans.use: to service his taxi.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 37 years old, married to Benson and blessed with five children aged 17, 15, 10, 6 and 4 years respectively. She sells maize, a business she started ten years ago, and earns a monthly income of 18,000 KES. 
Esther has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to purchase six bags of maize for resale. The anticipated profit will help her pay school fees for her children. Her dream is to one day own rental houses, educate her children and see her business expand. This is her first loan.

loans.use: to purchase six bags of dried maize for resale.

loans.name: Olenga

texts.en:
Olenga is 44 years old and lives in the town of Koboko in the Arua region of Uganda. He is married and has eight children, five of whom are currently in school. For the past 11 years, Olenga has been working hard to manage his small shop, which sells clothes. 
To help expand his business, Olenga has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to increase the stock in his business, and will help Olenga to generate greater profits and build a permanent house for himself. Olenga hopes that in the future he will be able to educate his children and expand his business. 
Olenga is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Olenga who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to increase the stock in his business.

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Violet is 40 years old, and she and her husband Morris are blessed with five children aged 19, 18, 15, six and two years. She has been selling tea leaves for two years and earns a monthly income of 10,000 KES. 

Violet has requested her first loan, at 10,000 KES, to purchase tea leaves and packaging materials. She dreams of buying a plot of land one day and building rooms for rent.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her tea selling business.

loans.name: Mujeres Empresarias Group

texts.es: Maura de 35 años de edad casada con 03 hijos aún dependientes. Con los deseos de superarse y mejorar su economía Maura decide estudiar un curso de repostería, con lo que aprendió decide emprender su propio negocio, donde actualmente se  dedica a la preparación y venta de postres como pasteles, empanada, etc , la cual los ofrece a pedidos. Gracias a este negocio a podido ayudar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar y con la educación de sus hijos. En esta oportunidad solicito el crédito para comprar insumos como harina, azúcar, leche, etc. y materiales como olla y molde. Su mayor deseo es de poner una tienda en su vivienda donde pueda ofrecer productos de primera necesidad. Maura es integrante de la Alcancía Comunal “Mujeres Empresarias” la cual está conformado por 09 personas responsables. Ellas agradecen el crédito brindado. Maura está ubicada en la parte de adelante es la primera del lado derecho viste un polo blanco y pantalón azul.
texts.en:
Maura is 35 years old and married with three still-dependent children. With a desire to better herself and improve her economic situation, Maura decided to take a pastry-making course. With what she learned, she decided to open her own business, where she currently works preparing and selling desserts like cakes, empanadas, etc., which she makes to order. Thanks to this business, she has been able to help her husband with household expenses and the education of their children. 

At this time, she requested the loan to buy supplies like flour, sugar, milk, etc., and equipment like pots and pans. Her greatest wish is to open a shop in her residence where she could offer basic products. 

Maura is a member of the communal bank Mujeres Empresarias, which is composed of nine responsible people. They are grateful for the loan granted. Maura appears on the right side of the picture, in the front row, dressed in a white t-shirt and blue pants.

loans.use: to buy supplies and baking equipment.

loans.name: Lea

texts.en:
Lea is 39 years old and married with two children. 
She has a small plantation where she grows taro, bananas and yams that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for five years. Lea needs a loan to purchase weed killer, a rake, knives and other farm supplies. 
She has been a member of SPBD since 2009. Lea will use the profits from her sales to pay for her children's school fees and help to renovate her home.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies for growing crops.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is 32 years old and lives in the town of Arua in the Arua region of Uganda. She is married and has five children, all currently in school. For the past 10 years, Lucy has been working hard to manage her small business selling small dry fish. 

To help expand her business, Lucy has requested a loan of 3,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fish for sale and will help Lucy generate greater profits and increase her capital. She hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business. 

Lucy is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Lucy who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy fish for sale.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is a farmer in Kitale, Western Kenya where he lives with his two children, one of whom is currently enrolled in college. He runs his farm with the help of one farmhand and produces mainly maize and beans, which he sells at the local market. 

Richard has requested a loan of 90,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to help him venture into the poultry farming business. He says there are great prospects for growth, owing to the lively regional market for poultry products. He will buy poultry for 40,000 KES and construct a housing unit for 50,000.

He faces challenges like costly and unreliable labor and poor road networks in the area. This is Richard's fourth loan, and he appreciates Juhudi Kilimo's services.

loans.use: to buy poultry and construct housing units.

loans.name: Sila

texts.en:
Silas is a 43-year-old man from Migori who is married to Hedwina. They have four children.

Silas operates a business cutting and repairing house keys. He has been in this business for the last 16 years. He makes a monthly income of KES. 15,000. He will use his first loan from KADET LTD to buy a key-cutting machine. 

He will use the profits to pay school fees for his children. His dream is to improve his family's living standards.

loans.use: To buy a key-cutting machine.

loans.name: Night

texts.en:
Night is 32 years old and lives in the town of Arua in the Arua region of Uganda. She is single and has four children. Three of them are currently in school. For the past four years, Night has been working hard to manage her small business which involves selling small dried fish. 

To help expand her business, Night has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fish for resale. It will help Night to generate greater profits and expand her business. Night hopes that in the future she will be able to grow her business. 

Night is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more small dried fish for resale.

loans.name: Tuvshintur

texts.en:
Tuvshintur is a 38-year-old married man who has three daughters and one son. He lives with his family in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia.  
He is a head of a dog factory that has two dog shops in the city. Since 2003, he has been operating a dog factory business, so he is very experienced with his work. Tuvshintur sells a variety of dog breeds, including the Tibetan hunt dog, which is shown in the picture. 
During the summer season, his business can attract more customers, so he is requesting a loan of 3,900,000 Mongolian Tugriks (MNT) to increase his current offering dog breeds.  “I really like to enjoy and feel the happiness from my job ecause it’s my hobby, and I really love the dogs because they are the person’s best friend,” Tuvshintur said happily.

loans.use: to increase his current offering of dog breeds

loans.name: Diosdado

texts.en:
Diosdado farms for a living. He and his wife cultivate their land to grow rice crops to sell. He is 46 years of age and married to Eliza, who raises hogs. They are blessed with three children and one adopted child.

Diosdado does his best to keep their farm productive. He has been working in this kind of business for seven years. Determined to have a better way of life, he applied for a loan in the amount of PHP 35,000 so he and his family can fund their farming business. He will use the loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and other farming materials. He knows that through this loan, his yield and income will increase, so he hopes that his loan request will be granted.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers, and other farming materials to improve his rice crop production.

loans.name: Eliza

texts.en: Eliza is married, 49 years old, and lives in Sebasi, Clarin, Misamis Occidental with her five kids. Eliza operates a sari-sari store to earn a living. She has been in this business for more than five years and earns 1,000 every month. She is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP to purchase supplementary goods for her general store. She joined GDMPC in 2008. In the future, Eliza will use her income to support her kids in their studies through college and also in their daily needs.

loans.use: to purchase supplementary goods for her general store.

loans.name: Semmy

texts.en:
Semmy is 40 years old and lives in the town of Packwach in the Arua region of Uganda. He is married with five children, three of whom are in school. For the past four years, Semmy has been working hard to manage his retail shop, where he sells sugar and soap. 

To help expand his business, Semmy has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential commodities for resale, and will help Semmy generate greater profits and pay the school fees for his children. Semmy hopes that in the future he will be able to own another business. 

Semmy is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more essential commodities for resale,

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy spare parts for his transport vehicle.

loans.name: Glenda Paola

texts.es:
La señorita Glenda Paola, tiene 26 años de edad, cursó su educación diversificada, se dedica al comercio, a la ventas de variedades, inicio este negocio con el fin de mejorar su condición de vida y hasta el momento lleva 5 años de experiencia.

Solicita un préstamo que lo utilizara para la compra de chamarras mexicanas y vender estaS, para mejorar su ingresos, espera seguir ampliando su negocio.
texts.en:
Glenda Paola, who is 26 years old, completed her secondary education and works in commerce selling varieties. She started this business with the aim of improving her quality of life and, as of now, has five years of experience. 

She is requesting a loan that she will use to purchase Mexican jackets to sell to improve her income. She hopes to continue expanding her business.

loans.use: to buy merchandise.

loans.name: Oscar Manuel

texts.es:
Oscar  es un hombre  que tiene  31 años de edad, de estado civil conviviente, con un hijo a su cargo, vive con su cónyuge y su hijo en casa propia. Se menciona que  La calidad de vida en la comunidad es de subsistencia, la mayoría de moradores  son trabajadores independientes  que se dedican al comercio, agricultura y ganadería. Oscar  vive  en el  caserío San Carranco del distrito de Jayanca, departamento de Lambayeque; así mismo cuenta con el servicio básico de energía eléctrica; también se menciona que en este distrito viven todas las  familias bajo estas condiciones.
La actividad comercial a la que se dedica Oscar es al transporte público de mototaxi el recorrido lo realiza entre las zonas de San Carranco  – Jayanca y visciversa. Además se dedica a la crianza y engorde de aves de corral, lo cual sus animales los comercializa a los mayoristas de la zona; cabe destacar que en esta actividad  de transporte público Oscar cuenta con 8 años de experiencia, lo que le ha permitido mantener su clientela ya establecida en este negocio. 
Actualmente  Oscar esta solicitando un nuevo préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa por un monto de S/. 2000 nuevos soles que será para el mantenimiento de su vehiculo (cambio de neumáticos, carpa y cambio de aceite),  y compra de alimentos para sus animales esto debido a que es una actividad muy rentable en la zona; lo cual en el tiempo le va permitir ir mejorando su nivel de vida con su familia.
texts.en:
Oscar is 31 years old and is in a common-law marriage with one child. He lives with his spouse and son in his own house. It is mentioned that quality of life in his community is at a subsistence level. Most residents are independent workers who work in commercial activities, agriculture, and stockbreeding. Oscar lives in the small village of San Carranco, within the district of Jayanca, in the department of Lambayeque. Also, he has access to basic electricity service. It is said as well that all families in this district live in these conditions.
Oscar's commercial activity is public transportation by mototaxi. He drives his route between the areas of San Carranco to Jayanca and back. He also works raising and fattening fowl, and sells his animals to wholesalers in the area. Notably, Oscar has eight years of experience in public transportation, which have allowed him to maintain an established customer base in this business.  
Currently Oscar is requesting a new loan from Edpyme Alternativa in an amount of 2000 nuevos soles, which he will use to maintain his vehicle (tire change, canvas, and oil change), and to purchase feed for his animals, since this is a very profitable activity in his area. This in time will allow him to gradually improve his family's living standards.

loans.use: to maintain his mototaxi and purchase feed to fatten his animals.

loans.name: Bonifacia Group

texts.es:
El grupo Bonifacia lo conforman tres mujeres trabajadoras y emprendedoras una de ellas es Bonifacia del Rosario quien tiene una pulpería la cual inicio con la venta de chiverias y refresco actualmente la tiene surtida con más variedad de productos; además vende truchas y ropa. Ella está casada con Ronaldo con quien tiene tres hijos e invertirá el crédito en granos básicos.
Las otras integrantes son Tomasita quien vende ropa desde hace 10 años de manera ambulante en Masatepe  y Anielka quien vende ropa y cosméticos desde hace 4 años.
texts.en:
The Bonifacia group is made up of three hard-working and enterprising women. One of them is Bonifacia del Rosario who has a small grocery store which she began by selling snacks and soft drinks and which she now stocks with a wider variety of products; she also sells trout and clothes. She is married to Ronaldo, with whom she has three children. She will use the loan to buy basic grains. 

The other members are Tomasita who has been selling clothes as a street vendor in Masatepe for 10 years, and Anielka who has been selling clothes and make-up for 4 years.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, cleaning products, dairy products, etc.

loans.name: Melchor

texts.en:
Melchor is a farmer living in San Sebastian Ramon. He primarily grows rice crops on his 1.4 hectare rice field. 

Melchor is 47 years old and married to Juvilyn, who is an Overseas Filipino Worker. The couple were blessed with three children. One of them has settled for marriage. One is single and working, while the youngest is still studying. Through the income generated from his farming business, he is able to help provide for his family's basic needs. Melchor plans to buy farming materials so he can prepare the farm plot to be planted but his income is not sufficient due to the expensive price of farming materials. Consequently, he is requesting a loan of PHP 40,000. He hopes to own a bigger farm in the future so he gives his full time running his farming business. In addition, he also hopes for his family's standard of living to improve and to be able to let his youngest child finish his studies.

loans.use: to buy farming materials so he can earn a bigger income to nourish the growth of his rice crop.

loans.name: Rodolfo

texts.en:
Rodolfo aims to have a better way of living and increase his income. To make his dream come true, he does his best to earn greater profits. 

Rodolfo has 1.5 hectares of farmland on which he grows rice crop. He has worked hard for seven years and made sacrifices to make his rice field productive. The income generated from his business has been used to sustain his family's needs and support their education. He spends much on his children's education because he would like to educate them. The capital intended for his farming business is no longer enough due to the high cost of basic commodities and increase of his children's allowances. Due to having insufficient funds for his farming business, he is asking for a loan of PHP 22,000 to buy necessary farming materials to improve the farm plot and and to pay for the cost of hired laborers in preparation for the plot to be planted.

He hopes that his loan will be approved so he can succeed.

loans.use: to buy necessary farming materials to improve the farm plot and to pay for the cost of hired laborers.

loans.name: Carol

texts.en:
Carol, 54, is from Aparri and has a variety store in the public market. She is a hardworking and loving mother of three grown children. She supported them through her business of selling caps, dresses, and bags. Her business also provided the funds for them to pursue their education. She wants them to finish their education because it is a long-lasting gift that she can give them.

To support their education, she is requesting additional working capital to improve her business. A 25,000 PHP loan will be used to purchase bags, toys, and different dresses. She hopes for the development of her precious business in order to provide a good education for her children.

loans.use: to purchase bags, toys, and different dresses

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
This is Rosalinda, 57, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is a single mother of 2 children.  She manages her own household while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Rosalinda maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics, and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalog. These are the profits that dealers make as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 6000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 31,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy merchandise and orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Rosalinda hopes to grow her business and increase her clients in the coming years. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week. These weekly meetings are also a place where she can draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for merchandise and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim has been in farming for ten years. He produces and sells maize, beans, and eggs to the local market to meet his family's needs. He is married and has four children between the ages of 18 and 11. 

Ibrahim has requested a second loan of 70,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy more poultry birds for his farm. He says farming is his only source of income and a boost into the business will help him provide for his family. He plans to educate his children with the major part of his farming income.

He says poor market prices and unreliable farmhands remain the major challenges to his farming business.

loans.use: To buy poultry birds

loans.name: Felicien

texts.en:
Felicien is married and has four children. Three of them are enrolled in school; the youngest is one month old. His wife works as a farmer. He has been a rice farmer for two years. He would like to get this Kiva loan to buy seeds and support labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, he plans to expand the area he has been using to get more output.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more seeds and support labor costs in the rice production.

loans.name: Maurice

texts.en:
Maurice is a resident of Kitale in Western Kenya, where he lives with his wife and five children, aged fifteen to three years. He has been actively farming for ten years and currently produces and sells maize potatoes and beans to the local market to meet his family needs. He runs a retail shop business besides farming.

Maurice has requested a first loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo. He will use the loan to buy poultry birds for a new venture into poultry farming. He hopes to expand his farming business and fully rely on farming income in the near future.

He identifies lack of capital, unreliable rains, and high costs of farm inputs as the major challenges.

loans.use: To buy poultry birds.

loans.name: Dioleta

texts.en:
This is Dioleta, 40, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. Her husband is Esteban, a sewer. Dioleta has four children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Dioleta operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries, and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 30,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Dioleta hopes her business will grow in the coming years and dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. The weekly meetings are where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Mikoroshini Group

texts.en:
Grace, who is in her late 40s, is married with two children who go to school. She has been selling fabric, sarongs, mandazi, and vitumbua for two years now. She works at 6:00 a.m. by selling mandazi and vitumbua and then at 10:00 a.m. she goes to sell fabrics and sarongs door-to-door up to 1:00 p.m. daily. From this, she is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be her 3rd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to buy more fabrics and sarongs, started selling cosmetics, and paid household expenses. She has paid back all of her loans successfully. She wants a loan to buy more fabrics, sarongs, 5 kilos of rice for vitumbua, 5 kilos of backing floor for mandazi, and to buy more cosmetics. Her dream is to one day be able to build her own house.

She will share this loan with her loan group "Mikoroshini" which has a total of 15 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more fabrics, sarongs, 5 kilos of rice for vitumbua, 5 kilos of backing floor for mandazi, and to buy more cosmetics

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is 45 years old and lives in the town of Pakwach in the Arua region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, three of them currently in school. For the past 15 years, Joyce has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells bags and home products. 

To help expand her business, Joyce has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more bags and home products like plates and saucepans for resale, and will help Joyce to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Joyce hopes that in the future she will be able to run two businesses of the same kind. 

Joyce is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Joyce who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more bags and home products like plates and saucepans for resale

loans.name: Bienestar (Flat) Group

texts.es:
El grupo se llama bienestar  que está integrado  por tres señoras y viven en una comunidad llamada Morelia que esta a media hora del la ribera trinidad.

  El señor Dora es quien se le tomo la entrevista, ella es casada con el señor Eliseo con quien procreo cuatro hijos quienes  aun están a su responsabilidad y están estudiando.

   Ella solicito el préstamo  para invertirlo en la compra de  maíz y frijol para después venderlo  por bulto o por quilo, en donde lleva trabajando  diez años , así también vende tamales dos veces por semana y le va muy bien.
  En esta actividad inicio  para apoyarse con sus ingresos y ano verse limitada con algunos gastos generados  en su hogar y también apoyare a su esposo para darle lo  más necesario a su familia.

   Lo  que desea  es que con el préstamo  logre seguir trabajando   para apoyar a su  familia hasta donde dios le preste vida.
 
  Quienes integran en el grupo son: María Bellanet quien invertir en la compra de cosméticos de la marca Avon y la señora María  Estela invertirá en la compra de alimentos para criar pollos de rancho y posteriormente venderlo.
texts.en:
The group is called “Bienestar” (Wellbeing) and it’s made up of three women living in a community called Morelia that’s half an hour from Ribera Trinidad.

Dora was the person interviewed.  She’s married to Eliseo and they have four children who are still dependent on them and attending school

She asked for the loan to buy corn and beans to then sell in bulk or by the kilogram; she’s been in business ten years.  She also sells tamales twice a week and does very well.

She started this business to help out with income and not be so limited with household expenses and also to help her husband to give her family what they need.

What she wants with the loan is to continue working to help her family for as long as God gives her life.

The members of the group are María Bellanet who will invest in Avon brand cosmetics and María Estela who will invest in the purchase of chicken feed to raise free-range chickens to then sell.

loans.use: to buy beans and corn.

loans.name: Xyndritz

texts.en:
Xyndritz is involved in the farming business. He has grown rice crops for three years. Aside from farming, he is also raising hogs as an additional source of income for his family. He has currently raised one sow and 11 piglets. He has been involved in this kind of business for one year. Xyndritz is a young man and married to Virginia. They are blessed with three school-aged children.

Xyndritz would like to increase his sales and profit because of their high household expenses and the daily maintenance of his raised hogs. He really needs additional capital because the capital intended for his farming business was used for his children's education and hog-raising business. For this reason, he is asking for a loan of PHP 30,000. He will use this loan to buy farm supplies and livestock feed for his hog-raising business. He hopes that he will make his farmland productive so that he can earn more income which will serve to give his children a bright future and cover all his household expenditures.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies for his farmland and livestock feed for the hogs he raises.

loans.name: Dionafe

texts.en:
This is Dionafe, 42, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. Her husband is Nelson, an employee. Dionafe and Nelson have children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Dionafe operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PH 500 in sales every day. 

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 30,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Dionafe hopes her business will grow in the coming years and dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. There, she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Anathalie

texts.en:
Anathalie is married with four children between the ages of 12 and 28. Currently two of her children attend school, while other two have started working for themselves. 

Anathalie has spent 20 years in rice production. She has requested a Kiva loan to buy more seeds and support labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, she plans to expand her cultivation area to increase output.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more seeds and support labor costs to get the best harvest

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia is a married woman with three children who are enrolled in school. Her husband sells fish to contribute to the family's basic needs. She lives in her own house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.

For the past two years, Rukia has been selling fresh fish in the market. Seasonality is one major challenge she faces. She aspires to own a well stocked cereal shop.

With the 10,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase fishing nets to expand her business. She decided to join Yehu to access funds to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase fishing nets.

loans.name: Benson

texts.en:
Benson has been in active farming for fifteen years in his rural home in Kitale, Western Kenya, where he lives with his family of three children, all of school age. His farm products, which are mainly milk, maize, and horticultural products, are all sold within the local market.

Benson has requested a loan of 40,000 KES from Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to buy poultry birds at 30,000 KES and expand the dairy unit at 10,000 KES. He is focusing on having a flock of five thousand in his farm.

He says the high costs of feed and unreliable rains are the challenges in farming.

loans.use: To buy poultry birds and expand his dairy unit.

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
This is Remedios, 47, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Amador, a driver. Remedios has three children. She, together with her children, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Remedios operates a school supplies business. It is where one can buy school supplies, like pens, bond paper, cards and the like without going to a bookstore. She gets the supplies at wholesale prices and sells them by the piece. Her store is located in their community market. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to school supplies to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Remedios dreams of giving her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. There, she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stocks of school supplies and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Deo

texts.en:
Deo is 28 years old and lives in the town of Packwach in the Arua region of Uganda. He is married and has one child who is currently in school. For the past four years, Deo has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells sugar and soap. 

To help expand his business, Deo has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock his shop, and will help Deo to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his child. Deo hopes that in the future he will be able to increase his stock. 

Deo is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Deo who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy stock for his store.

loans.name: Jean Baptiste

texts.en:
Jean Baptist is married with six children between five and twelve, two of whom are twins. All of his children are enrolled in school. Jean Baptist has spent 15 years in rice farming, and his wife also works as a farmer. He would like this Kiva loan so he can buy seeds and pay for labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, he plans to expand the farming area he has been using so he can increase his output.

The agricultural sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's GDP, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay for rice production labor.

loans.name: Guadalupe De Reyes Group

texts.es:
Doña crecencia es uno de los miembros del grupo Guadalupe de reyes, ella tiene la edad de 62 años, no tuvo la oportunidad de estudiar ya que platica que antes solo se le daba escuela a los varones y las mujeres se quedaban en casa a aprender a realizar las labores del hogar, ella esta casada con el señor Cristino y actualmente viven solos ya que sus hijos ya están casados. Doña crecencia platica que desde muy pequeña sus padres la enseñaron a trabajar y a pesar de que su esposo proove su hogar ella siempre busca la manera de ayudarlo ya que cada dia la situación economica es peor.

Doña Crecencia desde hace un poco mas de 10 años con el apoyo de su esposo habrio un pequeña tienda de abarrotes en su hogar con la intencion de ganar un poco de dinero extra y porque en su colonia casi no hay tiendas eso ayuda a que sus ventas aumenten, ella habré todos los días desde muy temprano y siempre le gusta tener su tienda surtida con un poquito de todo para que sus clientes siempre encuentren lo que busquen y vuelvan hacerle el gasto, tambien nos dice que les gusta dar un buen trato  para ganar clientes.

ella invertira este credito en la compra de aceite de cocina, comida enlatada, frijoles, arroz, refrescos, dulces, sabritas, pan dulce, galletas, sal , azucar , mayonesa, jabon y cloro pra resurtir su negocio.

ella desea que con esta inversion su negocio continue progresando y así tener una mejor calidad de vida 

los demas integrantes del grupo son:

deodora venta de ropa 
juaquin herreria 
Arturo albañileria
Joel Abarrotes
Alberta venta de antojitos 
Rosa Venta de antojitos
amelia venta de pollo 
Esperanza venta de pollo 
Dorotea Venta de antojitos 
Natalia venta de abarrotes 
Antonio cultivo de maiz 
Maria de jesus venta de ropa 
Cristina venta de refrescos
texts.en:
Crecencia is one of the “Guadalupe de Reyes” group members.  She’s 62 years old.  She never went to school because she says that back then school was only for boys and the girls stayed home to learn how to do domestic chores.  She’s married to Cristino and they currently live alone because their children are all married.  Crecencia relates that since she was little her parents taught her to work and even though her husband provides for their home she always looks for ways to help him since the economic situation is worse every day.

A little over ten years ago, Crecencia opened a small home-based grocery store to help her husband with the intention of earning a little extra money and because there are practically no stores in her neighborhood and this helps her sales to increase.  She’s open every day from very early on and she always likes to keep her store well stocked with a little bit of everything so that her customers will always find what they are looking for and will return to make their purchases; she also tells us that she enjoys providing good service in order to win over customers.

She will invest the loan in the purchase of cooking oil, canned food, beans, rice, soft-drinks, candy, Sabritas [brand of snacks], sweet bread, cookies, salt, sugar, mayonnaise, soap and chlorine bleach to stock her store.  She hopes that with this investment her business will continue to progress thus having a better quality of life.

The other group members are:

Deodora-clothing sales 
Joaquín-iron work 
Arturo-construction work
Joel-groceries
Alberta-fast-food snack sales 
Rosa-fast-food snack sales
Amelia-chicken sales 
Esperanza-chicken sales 
Dorotea-fast food snack sales
Natalia-grocery sales 
Antonio-corn farming
María de Jesus-clothing sales 
Cristina-soft-drink sales

loans.use: to buy stock merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Johnbosco

texts.en:
Johnbosco is 42 years old and lives in the town of Mityana in the Mubende region of Uganda. He is married and has 5 children. Four of them are currently in school. For the past year, Johnbosco has been working hard to manage his poultry business, which sells chicken. 

To help expand his business, Johnbosco has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more feed for the birds, and will help Johnbosco to generate greater profits and meet most of his family basic needs. Johnbosco hopes that in the future he will be able to own a big poultry farm. 

Johnbosco is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Johnbosco who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more feeds for his birds.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 40 years old and lives in the town of Mityana in the Mubende region of Uganda. She is married and has 4 children. Three of them are currently in school. For the past 16 years, Jane has been working hard to manage her bar, which sells drinks.
